item.description: Topic: Fluid Dynamics Torricelli’s Theorem The velocity of the fluid coming out of the spout is the same as the velocity of a single droplet of fluid that falls from the height of the ...

item.title: Equation of Continuity
item.description: Equation of Continuity Topic: Fluids The equation of continuity for fluids relates the rate of flow at one point to another, stating that they must be equal across the fluid ...

item.title: Navier-Stokes Equations
item.description: Topic: Fluid Dynamics Navier-Stokes Equations The Navier-Stokes Equations are a series of Partial Differential Equations that describe the motion of Fluids ...

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Hello, World! Hey there! I am Eben Quenneville, a Physics student at the University of New Hampshire. This is a publicly accessible sub-section of my personal notes network built using Obsidian.

item.title: Pascals Principle
item.description: Topic: Fluids Pascal’s Principle What is Pascal’s Principle? :?: The principle that the pressure throughout a fluid is equal. Formally, Pascal’s Principle might be defined as: A pressure change at any point in a confined and in-compressible fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid such that the same change occurs everywhere.

item.title: Pressure
item.description: Topic: Fluids Pressure \text{Pressure} = P = \frac{F}{A} Measured in Pascals: 1 Pa = 1 N / m^2. Also measured in kilopascals kPa, atmospheres 1 atm = 101.3 kPa, and pounds per square inch, 1 atm = 14.7 psi.

item.title: Van der Waals Equation of State
item.description: Topic: Fluids Van der Waals Equation of State The Ideal Gas Law is just that; ideal. It turns out that gases don’t behave exactly like this, especially as your approach high pressures.

item.title: Fluids
item.description: Fluids What is a fluid? :?: Something that flows, including gasses, liquids, and plasmas. What causes Pressure in a fluid? :?: The weight of the fluid and the collisions of the molecules.

item.title: Hydraulics
item.description: Topic: Fluids Hydraulics Hydraulics rely on Pascals Principle to give mechanical advantage in some way. For example, you might lift a car using a hydraulic lift that functions by putting some force on one piston with a small area that lifts a much larger piston by a smaller amount.

item.title: Vapor
item.description: Topic: Fluids Vapor A vapor is very similar to a gas. However, the difference is that a substance below its Critical Temperature in the gaseous state is called a vapor; above the critical temperature it is called a gas.
